Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Wins Above Replacement  A single number that presents the number of wins the player added  to the team above what a replacement player (think AAA or AAAA) would add.  Scale for a single-season: 8+ MVP Quality, 5+ All-Star Quality, 2+ Starter,  0-2 Reserve, < 0 Replacement Level    Developed by Sean Smith of BaseballProjection.com
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

This table lists the career, single-season, active, yearly (meaning
performances solely from that year) leaders following each season of
Major League Baseball. Note that a player is considered active between
the first and last season of their career.  Entries under
Single-Season from 1871-1875 are not carried forward past 1875.
Entries under Career and Active do include totals from
the 1871-1875 seasons.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Offensive Wins Above Replacement (everything but Fielding)  The same statistic as Wins Above Replacement for Position  Players (WAR), but with the fielding value excluded.  oWAR + dWAR does not equal WAR.  Adding would count positions twice.  Contains the factor for batting stats, baserunning, a positional adjustment, and the replacement player adjustment.   Factors developed by Sean Smith of BaseballProjection.com

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Defensive Wins Above Replacement for position players  A defensive measure of wins above replacement, but given  only the defensive stats of the player and his position adjustment.  For this calculation, we use a  replacement level on defense is the league average.  Based on Baseball Info Solutions defensive runs saved from 2003 on  and total zone rating developed by Sean Smith of BaseballProjection.com previously

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Hits/At Bats  For recent years, leaders need 3.1 PA  per team game played  Bold indicates highest BA using current stats  Gold means awarded title at end of year.
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
Career:
Statistic Description: Hits/At Bats  For recent years, leaders need 3.1 PA  per team game played  Bold indicates highest BA using current stats  Gold means awarded title at end of year.
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Minimum of
1000 IP,
3000 PA,
500 games
(fielding, 500 IP for Ps),
200 stolen base attempts
(catchers) or
80 stolen base attempts
(baserunners only since 1951) or
100 decisions
for career and active leaderboards for rate statistics.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Yearly League:
Statistic Description: Total Bases/At Bats or   (1B + 2*2B + 3*3B + 4*HR)/AB  For recent years, leaders need 3.1 PA  per team game played
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

the 1871-1875 seasons.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: OPS+  100*[OBP/lg OBP + SLG/lg SLG - 1]  Adjusted to the player’s ballpark(s)
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
Career:
Statistic Description: OPS+  100*[OBP/lg OBP + SLG/lg SLG - 1]  Adjusted to the player’s ballpark(s)
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Minimum of
1000 IP,
3000 PA,
500 games
(fielding, 500 IP for Ps),
200 stolen base attempts
(catchers) or
80 stolen base attempts
(baserunners only since 1951) or
100 decisions
for career and active leaderboards for rate statistics.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Runs Created  A set of formulas developed by Bill James and others  that estimates a player’s total contributions  to a team’s runs total.  This is computed with the "technical" formula when possible.  If SB or CS data is missing, the "basic" formula is used.  If HBP, IBB, SH, SF, or GIDP data is missing, the "stolen base" version of the formula is used.
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.

Statistic Description: Adjusted Batting Runs  A set of formulas developed by Gary Gillette, Pete Palmer and others  that estimates a player’s total contributions  to a team’s runs total via linear weights.  0.0 is an avg performance, <0 is worse than avg and >0 is better than avg

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Offensive Winning Percentage  The percentage of games a team with nine of this player  batting would win.  Assumes average pitching and defense.  This uses the Pythagorean win pct formula with the player's RC/G for runs scored and the league's R/9 as runs allowed. 
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
Career:
Statistic Description: Offensive Winning Percentage  The percentage of games a team with nine of this player  batting would win.  Assumes average pitching and defense.  This uses the Pythagorean win pct formula with the player's RC/G for runs scored and the league's R/9 as runs allowed. 
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Minimum of
1000 IP,
3000 PA,
500 games
(fielding, 500 IP for Ps),
200 stolen base attempts
(catchers) or
80 stolen base attempts
(baserunners only since 1951) or
100 decisions
for career and active leaderboards for rate statistics.

Statistic Description: Power/Speed Number  2 x (Home Runs x Stolen Bases)/(Stolen Bases + Home Runs)  The harmonic mean of HR and SB.  To do well you need a lot of both.  Developed by Bill James.

generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements

Statistic Description: Wins Above Replacement for Pitchers  A single number that presents the number of wins the player added  to the team above what a replacement player (think AAA or AAAA) would add.  This value includes defensive support and includes additional value for high leverage situations.  Scale: 8+ MVP Quality, 5+ All-Star Quality, 2+ Starter,  0-2 Reserve, < 0 Replacement Level     Developed by Sean Smith of BaseballProjection.com

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: 9 * ER / IP  For recent years, leaders need 1 IP  per team game played.  Bold indicates lowest ERA using current stats  Gold means awarded ERA title at end of year.
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

standards at that time to compute the top ten players for this
statistic.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: 9 x H / IP  For recent years, leaders need 1 IP  per team game played
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Statistic Description: 9 x H / IP  For recent years, leaders need 1 IP  per team game played
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Minimum of

500 games
(fielding, 500 IP for Ps),
200 stolen base attempts
(catchers) or
80 stolen base attempts
(baserunners only since 1951) or
100 decisions

Progressive:
Statistic Description: Home Runs Hit/Allowed
This table lists the career, single-season, active, yearly (meaning
performances solely from that year) leaders following each season of
Major League Baseball. Note that a player is considered active between
the first and last season of their career.  Entries under
Single-Season from 1871-1875 are not carried forward past 1875.
Entries under Career and Active do include totals from
the 1871-1875 seasons.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
Yearly League:
Statistic Description: Home Runs Hit/Allowed
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Statistic Description: Home Runs Hit/Allowed
This table lists the MLB top ten for each season
in this category.  When possible we have used the leaderboard
standards at that time to compute the top ten players for this
statistic.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: SO/W or SO/BB  For recent years, pitching leaders need 1 IP  per team game played.  No batting leaders computed.
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
Career:
Statistic Description: SO/W or SO/BB  For recent years, pitching leaders need 1 IP  per team game played.  No batting leaders computed.
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Minimum of
1000 IP,
3000 PA,
500 games
(fielding, 500 IP for Ps),
200 stolen base attempts
(catchers) or
80 stolen base attempts
(baserunners only since 1951) or
100 decisions
for career and active leaderboards for rate statistics.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Statistic Description: Adjusted Pitching Runs  A set of formulas developed by Gary Gillette, Pete Palmer and others  that estimates a pitcher’s total contributions  to a team’s runs total via linear weights.  0.0 is an avg performance, <0 is worse than avg and >0 is better than avg

Statistic Description: Base-Out Runs Saved  Given the bases occupied/out situation, how many runs did the pitcher  save in the resulting play.  Compared to average, so 0 is average, and  above 0 is better than average
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.

This statistic is computed from play-by-play data which is only
complete from 1973 to the present. From
1916-1972, the data is
incomplete, though for most seasons only less than 20 games per season
total are missing.  Please see our page on data coverage for a full view of the
data used to create these lists.

Statistic Description: Situational Wins (WPA/LI)  It is the sum of WPA divided by the leverage index for each play.  WPA depends greatly on the context of the at bats.  This stat does not.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Putouts
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements

Statistic Description: Assists
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements

Statistic Description: Range Factor per 9 Inn  9 * (Putouts + Assists) / Innings Played
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements

This statistic is computed from play-by-play data which is only
complete from 1973 to the present. From
1916-1972, the data is
incomplete, though for most seasons only less than 20 games per season
total are missing. Because of this, Career Range Factor/9 Innings Leaders are only considered for years 1973 to the present except for pitchers since we always know how many innings they were at the position. Please see our page on data coverage for a full view of the
data used to create these lists.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

This statistic is computed from play-by-play data which is only
complete from 1973 to the present. From
1916-1972, the data is
incomplete, though for most seasons only less than 20 games per season
total are missing. Because of this, Career Range Factor/9 Innings Leaders are only considered for years 1973 to the present except for pitchers since we always know how many innings they were at the position. Please see our page on data coverage for a full view of the
data used to create these lists.

only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements

This statistic is computed from play-by-play data which is only
complete from 1973 to the present. From
1916-1972, the data is
incomplete, though for most seasons only less than 20 games per season
total are missing. Because of this, Career Range Factor/9 Innings Leaders are only considered for years 1973 to the present except for pitchers since we always know how many innings they were at the position. Please see our page on data coverage for a full view of the
data used to create these lists.

For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
Minimum of
1000 IP,
3000 PA,
500 games
(fielding, 500 IP for Ps),
200 stolen base attempts
(catchers) or
80 stolen base attempts
(baserunners only since 1951) or
100 decisions
for career and active leaderboards for rate statistics.

This statistic is computed from play-by-play data which is only
complete from 1973 to the present. From
1916-1972, the data is
incomplete, though for most seasons only less than 20 games per season
total are missing. Because of this, Career Range Factor/9 Innings Leaders are only considered for years 1973 to the present except for pitchers since we always know how many innings they were at the position. Please see our page on data coverage for a full view of the
data used to create these lists.
This table lists the career, single-season, active, yearly (meaning
performances solely from that year) leaders following each season of
Major League Baseball. Note that a player is considered active between
the first and last season of their career.  Entries under
Single-Season from 1871-1875 are not carried forward past 1875.
Entries under Career and Active do include totals from
the 1871-1875 seasons.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Total Zone Total Fielding Runs Above Avg  The number of runs above or below average the player was worth based on the number of plays made.  This number combines the Rtz, Rdp, Rof, Rcatch numbers into a total defensive contribution.  See the glossary section for a more complete explanation.  Provided by BaseballProjection.com

0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
Minimum of
1000 IP,
3000 PA,
500 games
(fielding, 500 IP for Ps),
200 stolen base attempts
(catchers) or
80 stolen base attempts
(baserunners only since 1951) or
100 decisions
for career and active leaderboards for rate statistics.

This statistic is computed from play-by-play data which is only
complete from 1973 to the present. From
1916-1972, the data is
incomplete, though for most seasons only less than 20 games per season
total are missing. Because of this, Career Range Factor/9 Innings Leaders are only considered for years 1973 to the present except for pitchers since we always know how many innings they were at the position. Please see our page on data coverage for a full view of the
data used to create these lists.

For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
Year-by-Year Top-Tens:
Statistic Description: Fielding Percentage  (Putouts + Assists) / (Putouts + Assists + Errors)
This table lists the MLB top ten for each season
in this category.  When possible we have used the leaderboard
standards at that time to compute the top ten players for this
statistic.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Total Zone Total Fielding Runs Above Avg  The number of runs above or below average the player was worth based on the number of plays made.  This number combines the Rtz, Rdp, Rof, Rcatch numbers into a total defensive contribution.  See the glossary section for a more complete explanation.  Provided by BaseballProjection.com
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.

This statistic is computed from play-by-play data which is only
complete from 1973 to the present. From
1916-1972, the data is
incomplete, though for most seasons only less than 20 games per season
total are missing. Because of this, Career Range Factor/9 Innings Leaders are only considered for years 1973 to the present except for pitchers since we always know how many innings they were at the position. Please see our page on data coverage for a full view of the
data used to create these lists.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
Yearly League:
Statistic Description: Range Factor per 9 Inn  9 * (Putouts + Assists) / Innings Played
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements

This statistic is computed from play-by-play data which is only
complete from 1973 to the present. From
1916-1972, the data is
incomplete, though for most seasons only less than 20 games per season
total are missing. Because of this, Career Range Factor/9 Innings Leaders are only considered for years 1973 to the present except for pitchers since we always know how many innings they were at the position. Please see our page on data coverage for a full view of the
data used to create these lists.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

This table lists the MLB top ten for each season
in this category.  When possible we have used the leaderboard
standards at that time to compute the top ten players for this

+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.

Single-Season:
Statistic Description: Fielding Percentage  (Putouts + Assists) / (Putouts + Assists + Errors)
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Only players who finished in the top 40 for the majors in a season will appear on this list. Leaders from the current season are only included for rate stats after July 1st.
For batting rate stats, generally a minimum of
3.1 Plate Appearances/G, 1.0 IP/G,
0.67 Gm and Chances/Team Game (fielding),
0.2 SB att/Team Game (catchers), and
0.1 SB att/Team Game (baserunners only since 1951), and
0.1 decision/G for single-season leaderboards
generally needed for rate statistics.  For pitcher fielding the
minimums are reduced by a third.  For LF, CF, RF fielding stats, we
only have reliable data since 1901, so all leaders are since 1901.  Explanation of
min. requirements
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
Career:
Statistic Description: Fielding Percentage  (Putouts + Assists) / (Putouts + Assists + Errors)
Note that seasons prior to 1876 are not included in single-season marks, but are included in career marks.Minimum of
1000 IP,
3000 PA,
500 games
(fielding, 500 IP for Ps),
200 stolen base attempts
(catchers) or
80 stolen base attempts
(baserunners only since 1951) or
100 decisions
for career and active leaderboards for rate statistics.
+ - Indicates Hall of Famer.  Bold indicates active player. * - bats left-handed, # - bats both, else - bats right, ? - unknown.
